raw_text:
UK heading wrong way - Howard
 
 Tony Blair has had the chance to tackle the problems facing Britain and has failed, Michael Howard has said.
 
 "Britain is heading in the wrong direction", the Conservative leader said in his New Year message. Mr Blair's government was a "bossy, interfering government that takes decisions that should be made by individuals," he added. But Labour's campaign spokesman Fraser Kemp responded: "Britain is working, don't let the Tories wreck it again". Mr Howard also paid tribute to the nation's character for its generous response to the Asian quake disaster. The catastrophe was overshadowing the hopes for the future at this usually positive time of the year, Mr Howard said.
 
 "We watched the scenes of destruction with a sense of disbelief. The scale, the speed, the ferocity of what happened on Boxing Day is difficult to grasp. "Yet Britain's response has shone a light on our nation's character. The last week has shown that the warm, caring heart of Britain beats as strong as ever." He went on to reflect on the values that "most Britons hold dear". Looking ahead to the coming general election, he pledged to "turn these beliefs into reality" and set out the choices he says are facing Britain. "How much tax do people want to pay? Who will give taxpayers value for money, the clean hospitals and good, disciplined schools they want? "Who can be trusted to get a grip on the disorder on our streets and the chaos in our immigration system?"
 
 Mr Blair has failed to tackle these problems, he claimed, saying he has the "wrong solution" to them.
 
 "The result is big government and higher taxes eroding incentives, undermining enterprise and denying people choice. "Worst of all, it is a government that has wasted people's money and failed to tackle the problems families face today." The Tories, he said, can cut crime and improve public services without asking people to pay more taxes. "We can have progress without losing what makes Britain great - its tolerance, the respect for the rule of law, the ability of everyone to fulfil their potential. "We simply need to change direction. The election will give Britain the chance to change." This is the record Mr Blair will have to defend in the coming months, he said, urging voters to hold him to account.
 
 But Labour spokesman Mr Kemp said: "It would be more appropriate for this message to come out on 1 April, not 1 January." "Let us never forget that when Michael Howard was in government Britain suffered mass unemployment, 15% interest rates, record home repossessions, and the introduction of the poll tax. "With Labour Britain is working. Rather than alluding to false promises Michael Howard should be starting 2005 with an apology to the British people for the misery that the government, of which he was a member, inflicted upon the country.
llama3.2:1b:
UK heading wrong way - Howard
Tony Blair said his government has failed in addressing Britain's problems.
Michael Howard responded by saying Britain is "heading in the wrong direction" and praising its character in response to the Asian earthquake disaster.
Howard praised Labour's response but also criticized the government for having high taxes and wasteful spending, saying it erodes incentives and undermines enterprise.
llama3.2:3b: Tony Blair failed to tackle Britain's problems, says Michael Howard.
Howard claims Labour has "wrong solution" and big government erodes incentives.
He praises Britain's response to Asian quake disaster and pledges to turn values into reality.
Blair attacks Tories as failing to cut crime without raising taxes, while Labour spokesman Fraser Kemp accuses Howard of apologizing for his own party's mistakes.
gemma2:2b: Michael Howard criticizes Tony Blair's government for its direction and policies.
He believes Britain is in decline under Labour, citing increased taxes and government intervention as contributing factors.
On the other hand, Mr. Kemp argues that under Labour, the economy is performing well, highlighting Labour's record of addressing issues like unemployment and poverty.
Howard pledges to address these problems by "changing direction" through a Tory-led government, while claiming his party will deliver value for taxpayers without increasing taxes.
qwen2.5:0.5b: UK Prime Minister Tony Blair has been successful in his efforts but Labour leader Gordon Brown is not as successful, although he will face criticism due to the issues facing the UK economy and society.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Conservative leader Tony Blair has been criticized by former Prime Minister Michael Howard for failing to address Britain's problems, while Labour candidate Fraser Kemp defends Blair's policies as effective and working well in general.
Howard highlights Britain's response to natural disasters but argues that the next election should focus on improving public services and reducing taxes without increasing them.
qwen2.5:3b: Michael Howard claimed Tony Blair's government has taken decisions individuals should make and failed to tackle Britain’s problems such as crime and public services.
He criticized Labour for spending taxpayers' money inefficiently.
In contrast, he proposed cutting crime and improving services without increasing taxes.
Howard highlighted values most Britons hold dear and pledged to turn these beliefs into reality, focusing on issues like healthcare, schools, street disorder, and immigration control.
He urged voters to judge Blair's performance in the upcoming election.
Labour spokesman Fraser Kemp criticized this timing and called for an apology from Michael Howard for his government’s mismanagement of Britain during his tenure.
opencoder:1.5b: The UK Heading Wrong Way - Howard scenario presents a detailed narrative of a failed attempt by Tony Blair to reform and modernize Britain's foreign policy in response to concerns over rising Asian disruptions.
It also details a tribute to Michael Howard's character for his response to the disaster.
However, it is important to note that this information cannot be completely preserved due to formatting and explanations added during the text's creation.
smollm:1.7b: The UK heading wrong way - Howard
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Tony Blair has faced an opportunity to address Britain's problems but failed, criticizing his government as "bossy" and interfering in decision-making.
Labour's spokesman, Fraser Kemp, suggested a better start on January 1st by relating it to a similar event Michael Howard was involved in during 2005.
Both leaders are addressing the current economic crisis with different focuses.

tinydolphin:1.1b: A summary of the text provided: Michael Howard's tenure as leader of the Conservative Party and UK Prime Minister from 1995-2001 has been marked by major economic and social policy failures, with Britain heading in the wrong direction according to Tony Blair.

The Prime Minister hopes to turn this situation around by focusing on progress without losing what makes Britain great - its tolerance, the respect for the rule of law, and the ability of everyone to fulfill their potential.
phi:2.7b: The text provides a New Year message from Conservative leader Michael Howard, in which he criticizes the Labour government led by Tony Blair for failing to address key issues facing Britain and offering solutions that would not involve higher taxes.

He praises the generosity of British citizens in response to the Asian earthquake disaster but acknowledges the challenges ahead in addressing voter concerns about crime, public services, and immigration.
Howard pledges to change direction and improve the country's situation without increased taxation and urges voters to hold him accountable.
Labour's spokesperson responds that Howard should apologize for his party's mistakes during its time in government.
orca-mini:3b: The text discusses how Michael Howard criticized Tony Blair's government, saying it had failed to tackle problems facing Britain and had increased big government and higher taxes.
He also claimed that Blair had the wrong solution to these problems.
hermes3:3b:
UK heading wrong direction, says Michael Howard
- Tony Blair failed to tackle problems
- Britain working, don't let Tories wreck it again (Labour spokesman)
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Michael Howard criticized Tony Blair for not tackling the problems facing Britain and described Britain as heading in the wrong direction.
He praised the nation's character during the Asian quake disaster and reflected on the choices facing Britain in the upcoming general election.

However, Labour's campaign spokesman Fraser Kemp responded by emphasizing that Britain is working and urging voters to hold Michael Howard accountable for the mistakes made under his previous government.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Michael Howard criticized Tony Blair's government in his New Year message, claiming Britain is heading in the wrong direction due to excessive government interference, high taxes, and wasted public funds.
He argued that the Conservatives could improve public services and reduce crime without raising taxes, pledging to turn British values into reality.
He also praised the nation's generosity in responding to the Asian tsunami disaster.
Labour's Fraser Kemp dismissed Howard's claims, defending Blair's record and warning against a return to Conservative policies, citing past economic struggles under their leadership.
stablelm2:1.6b: Conservative leader Michael Howard says UK Prime Minister Tony Blair's government has failed to tackle issues facing Britain and is heading in the wrong direction.
Howard also criticized the response to the Asian quake disaster, while Labour campaign spokesman Fraser Kemp defended the government's performance.

Howard acknowledged Britain's generous response to the crisis as a reflection of the nation's character, but urged voters to hold Michael Howard accountable for past policies that caused mass unemployment, high interest rates, and other problems during his time in office.
granite3.1-dense:2b: In his New Year message, Conservative leader Michael Howard criticized Tony Blair's government for steering Britain "in the wrong direction," describing it as "bossy and interfering."
He argued that Labour's policies of big government and higher taxes have eroded incentives, undermined enterprise, and failed to address family issues.
Howard pledged to turn people's values into reality by offering alternatives: lower taxes for better public services and improved discipline on streets and immigration.
Fraser Kemp, Labour's campaign spokesman, countered that Britain is thriving due to the party's leadership during Howard's tenure as prime minister.

He highlighted past Conservative missteps, including mass unemployment, high interest rates, record home repossessions, and the introduction of the poll tax, urging voters to hold Blair accountable for these historical issues.
Howard also praised Britain's response to the Asian quake disaster, highlighting it as a testament to the nation's compassionate character.
